Meaning IN CONTEXT: neutral; neither unpleasant nor pleasant; neither comfortable nor uncomfortable
Commentary: (VINa) adukkham'asukhan'ti dukkh'ābhāvena adukkhaṃ, sukh'ābhāvena asukhaṃ. eten'ettha dukkhasukhapaṭipakkhabhūtaṃ tatiyavedanaṃ dīpeti, na dukkhasukhābhāvamattaṃ. tatiyavedanā nāma, adukkhamasukhā, upekkhā'ti'pi vuccati. sā iṭṭh'āniṭṭhaviparīt'ānubhavanalakkhaṇā, majjhattarasā, avibhūtapaccupaṭṭhānā, sukhanirodhapadaṭṭhānā'ti veditabbā.
Example1: sukham'pi vedayati, dukkham'pi vedayati, adukkham'asukham'pi vedayati. vedayatī'ti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā vedanā'ti vuccati.
Example3: n'eva tasmiṃ samaye dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, na adukkham'asukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti
Example4: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubb'eva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅ'gamā, adukkham'asukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
eng-old: neutral; neither pleasant nor unpleasant; neither comfortable nor uncomfortable
Feedback: Spot a mistake? Fix it here.

Meaning IN CONTEXT: (vinaya) defeated; deposed; disqualified; expelled; lit. who has been conquered
Commentary:
(VIN 6.8.5) pārājikan'ti yaṃ vuttaṃ,
taṃ suṇohi yathātathaṃ,
cuto paraddho bhaṭṭho ca,
saddhammā hi niraṅkato,
saṃvāso'pi tahiṃ n'atthi,
ten'etaṃ iti vuccati.
(VINa) pārājiko'ti parājito, parājayaṃ āpanno.
Notes: Indic Languages in Brill's Encyclopedia of Buddhism: "Similarly, the correct derivation and original meaning of the legal technical term pārājika based on the Vedic verb parā + aj-, "to drive away," probably originally belonging to the vocabulary of cattle keepers and therefore unknown to the Buddhist tradition, which sought a connection to parā + ji-, "to defeat" (pārājika > pārājayika), were found out by one of the pioneers of Western Buddhist studies, E. Burnouf, as early as 1844 and confirmed again by H. Smith in 1966 (von Hinüber, 1988, 3)"

Example3: dve kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā, sabbanimittānañ'ca amanasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāro.

Notes: (BDN) they are unshakable by their opposites: (1) the power of faith is unshakable by faithlessness (unbelief); (2) energy, by laziness; (3) mindfulness, by forgetfulness; (4) concentration, by distractedness; (5) wisdom, by ignorance. Meaning IN CONTEXT: who has perfect knowledge; who has complete understanding
Commentary:
(MNa) catumaggañāṇasaṅkhātehi vedehi akusaladhammānaṃ gatattā vedagū hoti, viditattā'ti attho.
(THa) vedagū'ti vedena gato maggañāṇena nibbānaṃ gato adhigato, cattāri vā saccāni pariññā-pahāna-sacchikiriyā-bhāvan'ābhisamayavasena abhisamecca ṭhito.
(SNa) jātu vedagū'ti ahaṃ ek'aṃsen'eva vedagū, vedasaṅkhātena ñāṇena neyyesu gato, vedaṃ vā gato adhigato, paṇḍito'ham'asmī'ti attho.
Example1: kathañ'ca bhikkhu vedagū hoti? vidit'āssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṃkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṃ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā
Example2:
sa ve samm'addaso bhikkhu, parijānāti vedanā.
so vedanā pariññāya, diṭṭhe dhamme anāsavo.
kāyassa bhedā dhammaṭṭho, saṅkhyaṃ n'opeti vedagū'ti.
eng-old: who has perfect knowledge; complete understanding; lit. gone through the Vedas
Feedback: Spot a mistake? Fix it here.
